captions.text: [Intro Music]

Starfield, or to give it its full title, 
Starfield and Friends (he he he he) is the

long-awaited new action-RPG by Bethesda, which by 
all accounts is what the lazy bastards have been

making instead of the Elder Scrolls 6 or a non-
shitty Fallout game, but who the hell needs those

when you can have a game with a whole galaxy of 
explorable planets.

Where there could be an Elder
Scrolls planet and a Fallout planet and a littlest

hobo planet and a planet made of meringue,
why not, when space exploration&#39;s on the cards,
not even the sky&#39;s the limit.
So how did Starfield turn out?

Now we&#39;ve established that it oozes
potential like a poorly made Big Mac does Thousand Island
Dressing.

Well, it&#39;s... it&#39;s...
it&#39;s... it&#39;s... it&#39;s... huh.

It&#39;s... it&#39;s... it&#39;s
really bloody boring as it happens.

I&#39;ll say this though, this is absolutely
the game for you if you&#39;re really, really into
doors.

If you&#39;re openly door sexual and get
illicit thrills from watching a staggering variety

of sci-fi doors open in every
imaginable direction with lots of little fiddly bits

and lights and hissing noises then Starfield
will get you more excited than the MST3K countdown
sequence ever did.

The story begins with our faceless knob end
protagonist working in a mine, where we discover

a mysterious relic left behind by an
advanced precursor alien civilisation and touching

it makes you have a fairly nondescript
mystic vision of distant galaxies, so already we&#39;ve

knocked out four squares on our space
game bingo card, the rest of which get knocked

out when a charismatic devil may care
scoundrel space pilot shows up, and says &quot;Oh you&#39;ve

found an alien artefact, now you get to
join our Super Friends Treehouse Club for Super

Great Explorers, random
impoverished miner with snot in their beard.&quot;

Here&#39;s a free spaceship, and then to
continue the plot you have to go to what looks like

a Victorian era smoking room where a
bunch of braying posh gits who might as well be

wearing monocles and pith helmets
patronise you rigid and tell you that going out and

finding more alien artefacts would
be rollicking great jolly hockey sticks.

And I think that was the first time I
realised I was the complete opposite of engaged.
Vacant, possibly.

I thought back fondly to the opening of
Skyrim, where you come within a chapinch&#39;s labia of

getting decapitated, before a twatting
great dragon shows up and atomises anything that&#39;s
as much as resemble to hockey stick.
Where are the thrills?
Where are the stakes?

Why should we care about gathering more
vision-inducing alien artefacts except that they provide an

inexpensive mellow hide
that the FDA hasn&#39;t regulated yet?

Probably for the best that a James A.
Starfield has the usual Bethesda RPG broad range of

side content exploration and gameplay
activities, with a hefty dollop of no-man&#39;s sky in the

middle to which everything else clings
like a parasitic crab, so there&#39;s several hundred

planets with literally no end of
procedurally generated landscapes every colour of the rainbow

to explore, and a whole
seven or eight different plants.

And of course you can build a base if
there&#39;s something about this one sky and its specific

shade of mushy pea green
that sets up your nesting instinct.

And so as I&#39;m searching a room for ammo,
health packs and valuables, virtually every sodding

random object says &quot;This is a
crafting ingredient, don&#39;t throw this away!&quot;
Crafting ingredient?
For what?
Well, we can&#39;t just tell you.

You&#39;ll have to load up your entire
cocking inventory space with garbage on the off chance

that some future upgrade
you want will call for some of it.
Ooh, I quite like this damage upgrade for my gun.

That&#39;ll be six beryllium,
one capacitor and a toast rack.

Oh, just my luck, I only brought nine
chlorine, one fish slice and a light emitting diode.

The Critical Path plot then took me to
an alien temple where, after completing possibly

the most facile minigame imaginable
which involved almost literally jumping through

hoops, the game unlocked my first cosmic
superpower, sort of its equivalent of the Skyrim Dragon

Shouts, only in this case one that
appeared to just disturb all the polystyrene cups within
a six foot radius.

So I made the commander decision at that
point to kick the main plot in the head and indulge

myself with some of that
idiosyncratic Bethesda RPG pissing about.

I took a side mission to survey the Tau
Ceti system, which did a lot to confirm that when

you&#39;ve procedurally generated one
planetary wilderness you&#39;ve procedurally generated them

all, but it gave me a direction to head
in and I did get embroiled in a conflict between

a pirate group and the local settlers, and
then I was having more fun because I was adventuring
on my own terms.

The space battling&#39;s functional enough,
if not exactly mind-blowing, and the same is
true of the ground level shooting.

Although I did have to carry about
twelve different guns, because the game&#39;s got more

ammo types than a vending
machine at a Texan middle school.

Still, functional is a big step for a
Bethesda RPG, because everything else is infused with
the usual jankiness.

The old Bioware face issue is very much
in evidence, every NPC talks to you like a deer
trying to smart-mouth a set of headlights.

I noticed upon raiding the pirate base
with a platoon of angry farmers that the gap-toothed

shitwits left me to deal with most of
the enemy by myself, while they milled around

in the lobby trying to
figure out how elevator buttons work.

Oh, and at some point the game said I
committed a crime but wouldn&#39;t tell me what it was.

I&#39;m sixty percent certain I didn&#39;t, but
one of the factions suddenly had a bounty on my

head and my helper NPC
at the time got really pissy.

I tried asking them what I&#39;d done, but
obviously the game wasn&#39;t smart enough to track that,
so he could only talk around it.

&quot;Hey dude, why are you
so pissed all of a sudden?&quot;
&quot;You know perfectly well why.&quot;
&quot;I really don&#39;t, I&#39;m trying to figure that out.&quot;

&quot;The fact you don&#39;t
know is making me even madder.&quot;

&quot;I don&#39;t remember taking any flirty
conversation options, why have you turned into my wife?&quot;

So then I thought I&#39;d just dodge bounty
hunters till I could reach a police station and pay

the fine, but as I tried
to do so the police kidnapped me.

And I woke up in a cell with a bloke
saying &quot;We&#39;re recruiting you as an undercover agent,

because the horrible crime you committed
shows you&#39;re the perfect candidate to infiltrate
the pirates.

Could someone please
explain what I&#39;m knobbing well did?&quot;

So my immersion was pretty broken by
that point if it had ever had a chance to fully
assemble.

It&#39;s hard to drink in the grandeur of
space travel when it seems like you spend more time

navigating menus than you do in the
cockpit and basically have to fast travel everywhere
you go.

It&#39;s like me saying I visited Singapore,
because my plane stopped to refuel there once but

I didn&#39;t actually get off because I&#39;d
finally gotten my seat cushioned to exact right buttock
proportions.

So I don&#39;t recommend Andrew Starfield
functional as some of it is, because it just bored me.

One minute it&#39;s No Man&#39;s Sky, the next
it&#39;s Mass Effect, then it&#39;s Cyberpunk for a bit

because we&#39;re in the one city
with lots of neon signs called Neon.
Bet that was a gruelling brainstorming session.

But what it never is is a game
with any clear identity of its own.

As the Frustrated Removals man said while
attempting to fit the contents of an observatory

through the front door, this is
what happens when your scope gets too broad.
[Outro Music]
[Outro Music]
